course_title: The Inner Lives of Black Women
original_descr: This course encourages students to use creative and rigorous historical methods to recover Black women's lives from the nineteenth century to the present.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: The Inner Lives of Black Women

Expanded Description: This course invites students to explore the multifaceted experiences and contributions of Black women from the nineteenth century to the present. Through a blend of creative expression and rigorous historical analysis, students will examine primary sources, literature, and personal narratives to uncover the complexities of identity, resilience, and activism. Engaging in discussions and projects, participants will reflect on societal challenges and triumphs faced by Black women throughout history, fostering a deeper understanding of their pivotal roles. By the end of the course, students will appreciate the rich tapestry of Black women's lives and their enduring impact on society.

original_descr: Continuation of AMHRLANG 2. Prerequisite AMHRLANG 2. Fulfills the University Foreign Language Requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Amharic, Third Quarter

This course serves as a continuation of AMHRLANG 2, building on foundational skills acquired in prior classes. Students will enhance their proficiency in Amharic through immersive language exercises, focusing on vocabulary expansion, grammar intricacies, and conversational practice. Emphasis will be placed on cultural context, enabling students to engage meaningfully with Amharic-speaking communities. By the end of the quarter, learners will confidently navigate everyday conversations, comprehend simple texts, and appreciate the nuances of Ethiopian culture. This course fulfills the University Foreign Language Requirement, making it an essential step for students seeking to deepen their language learning journey.

original_descr: Allows for qualified students to undertake investigations sponsored by individual faculty members. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Undergraduate Research

Expanded Description: This course provides qualified students with the unique opportunity to engage in independent research projects under the mentorship of individual faculty members. Students will collaborate closely with their instructors to develop research questions, design experiments, and analyze data within their field of study. Through this hands-on experience, participants will enhance their critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills, while gaining valuable insights into the research process. Students must obtain consent from their instructor prior to enrollment, ensuring alignment with faculty expertise and resources. This course is ideal for those seeking to deepen their understanding of academic research and contribute to ongoing scholarly work.

original_descr: Completes first-year sequence in two rather than three quarters.  Prerequisite: Placement Test, completion of ARABLANG 1A.  This course fulfills the University Foreign Language Requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Accelerated First-Year Arabic, Part II

Expanded Description: Accelerated First-Year Arabic, Part II is designed to complete the first-year Arabic language sequence in an intensive format over two quarters. Building on skills developed in ARABLANG 1A, students will enhance their proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing Arabic. The course emphasizes practical communication and cultural understanding, utilizing immersive activities, interactive exercises, and authentic materials. Students will engage in conversations, explore Arabic literature, and gain insights into various Arab cultures. Successful completion of this course fulfills the University Foreign Language Requirement, equipping students with essential language skills for future studies or travel.

original_descr: Continuation of ARABLANG 2.  One-year sequence designed to develop beginning proficiency, emphasizing reading and writing standard Arabic. Fulfills the University Foreign Language Requirement. Prerequisite: Placement Test, ARABLANG 2.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Arabic, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course is a continuation of ARABLANG 2 and is part of a comprehensive one-year sequence aimed at developing foundational proficiency in Arabic. Students will further enhance their reading and writing skills in standard Arabic, focusing on vocabulary expansion and grammatical structures. Expect engaging activities that promote conversational practice, cultural insights, and exposure to Arabic literature. This class emphasizes practical language use, preparing students for real-world communication. Successful completion fulfills the University Foreign Language Requirement. Prerequisites include a placement test or successful completion of ARABLANG 2, ensuring students are adequately prepared for this level.

original_descr: Completes second-year sequence in two rather than three quarters. For students with previous knowledge of Arabic. Prerequisite: Placement Test, ARABLANG 2A or 3.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Accelerated Second-Year Arabic, Part I

Expanded Description: This intensive course is designed to complete the second-year Arabic curriculum within two quarters, catering to students who possess prior knowledge of the language. Through immersive lessons, students will enhance their proficiency in reading, writing, listening, and speaking Arabic, focusing on expanding vocabulary and complex grammatical structures. Engaging with authentic materials, including literature, media, and cultural texts, students will deepen their understanding of Arabic-speaking cultures. Active participation in discussions and collaborative projects will foster communication skills. Prerequisites include a placement test or successful completion of ARABLANG 2A or 3, ensuring an appropriate skill level for all participants.

original_descr: Continuation of ARABLANG 22. One-year sequence designed to develop intermediate proficiency, with additional emphasis on functional applications and reading and writing standard Arabic. Prerequisite: Placement Test, ARABLANG 22.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Second-Year Arabic, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of ARABLANG 22, furthering students' journey towards intermediate proficiency in Arabic. Emphasizing practical communication skills, students will engage in immersive activities that enhance their ability to use Arabic in real-world contexts. The curriculum focuses on expanding vocabulary, refining grammar, and improving reading and writing skills in standard Arabic. Through diverse texts, cultural discussions, and interactive exercises, students will deepen their understanding of the language and its nuances. Successful completion requires a placement test or prior completion of ARABLANG 22, ensuring that all participants are adequately prepared for this enriching experience.

original_descr: Group meetings provide peer critiques, motivations, and advice under the direction of the Associate Dean.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: MLA Thesis in Progress

Description: This course facilitates a collaborative and supportive environment where students actively engage in group meetings focused on their thesis projects. Under the guidance of the Associate Dean, participants will present their work for peer critiques, fostering constructive feedback that enhances their research quality. Students will also receive motivational support and strategic advice tailored to their specific challenges and goals. Emphasizing the importance of community in academic success, this course encourages interdisciplinary dialogue, helping students refine their arguments, strengthen their writing, and develop a clear thesis statement, ultimately progressing toward the successful completion of their MLA thesis.

original_descr: Introduction to techniques, materials, and vocabulary in oil painting. Still life, landscape, and figure used as subject matter. Emphasis is on painting and drawing from life. (lower level)
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Painting I

Expanded Description: This foundational course introduces students to the essential techniques, materials, and vocabulary of oil painting. Through engaging projects focusing on still life, landscape, and figure painting, students will explore the nuances of color theory, composition, and brushwork. A significant emphasis is placed on painting and drawing from life, enabling learners to develop their observational skills and artistic expression. Students will also engage in critiques to foster a deeper understanding of artistic concepts and personal styles. By the end of the course, participants will have a solid foundation in oil painting, preparing them for more advanced artistic endeavors.

course_title: Accelerated First- Year American Sign Language -2nd Qtr
original_descr: Completes first-year sequence in two rather than three quarters. Course emphasizes development of comprehension and production skills using daily life topics. Focus on cultural awareness necessary for communication.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Accelerated First-Year American Sign Language - 2nd Qtr

This accelerated course completes the first-year American Sign Language sequence in just two quarters, allowing students to rapidly develop essential ASL skills. Emphasizing both comprehension and production, students will engage with practical topics related to daily life, enhancing their ability to communicate effectively in various contexts. Additionally, the course will incorporate cultural awareness components, providing insights into Deaf culture and the nuances of non-verbal communication. Through interactive activities, group discussions, and immersive practice, students will build confidence and fluency in ASL, preparing them for further studies and meaningful interactions within the Deaf community.

original_descr: Conversation, grammar, reading, elementary composition. Daily sections may be set at the beginning of the quarter to suit schedule requirements.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Modern Chinese, First Quarter

Expanded Description: This introductory course in Modern Chinese is designed for beginners eager to embark on a journey into the Chinese language and culture. Students will engage in fundamental conversational skills, essential grammar rules, and basic reading comprehension, all tailored to enhance language acquisition. Emphasis will be placed on developing elementary composition skills, allowing students to express themselves in written Chinese. Daily sections will be organized at the beginning of the quarter to accommodate various schedules, ensuring flexibility. Through interactive activities, students will build confidence and a solid foundation in Mandarin Chinese, preparing them for continued language learning.

original_descr: Continuation of CHINLANG 1.  Daily sections may be set at the beginning of the quarter to suit schedule requirements.Prerequisite: placement test, CHINLANG 1.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Modern Chinese, Second Quarter

Expanded Description: Building upon the foundational skills acquired in CHINLANG 1, this course continues to develop proficiency in Modern Chinese through interactive lessons that emphasize speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Students will engage in daily activities designed to enhance vocabulary and grammar understanding while exploring cultural contexts. Structured to accommodate diverse schedules, daily sections will be arranged at the beginning of the quarter to maximize accessibility. Students are required to complete a placement test or have successfully completed CHINLANG 1. By the end of this course, learners will gain increased confidence in their language abilities and cultural awareness.

original_descr: Continuation of CHINLANG 2. Daily sections may be set at the beginning of the quarter to suit schedule requirements. Fulfills the University language requirement. Prerequisite: Placement Test, CHINLANG 2.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Modern Chinese, Third Quarter

Description: This course serves as a continuation of CHINLANG 2, further enhancing students’ proficiency in Modern Chinese through an immersive and interactive approach. Students will expand their vocabulary, grammar, and conversational skills, focusing on practical applications in everyday contexts. Daily sections will be organized at the start of the quarter to accommodate various student schedules. Engaging activities such as role-plays, dialogues, and cultural discussions will enrich the learning experience, fostering a deeper understanding of Chinese culture. Completion fulfills the University language requirement. Prerequisites include a successful placement test or completion of CHINLANG 2. Join us for an exciting linguistic journey!

original_descr: Continuation of CHINLANG 22. Listening, speaking, reading, writing. Daily sections may be set at the beginning of the quarter to suit schedule requirements. Prerequisite: Placement Test, CHINLANG 22.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Second-Year Modern Chinese, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of CHINLANG 22, focusing on enhancing students’ proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Modern Chinese. Through engaging activities such as interactive dialogues, group discussions, and written assignments, students will deepen their understanding of Chinese culture and language nuances. Daily sections will be tailored at the start of the quarter to accommodate varied schedule needs, ensuring flexibility and accessibility for all participants. A prerequisite for enrollment includes either a successful placement test or completion of CHINLANG 22, ensuring that all students are adequately prepared for this immersive learning experience.

course_title: Second-Year Chinese for Bilingual Students, Third Quarter
original_descr: Continuation of CHINLANG 22B. For students with advanced comprehension and speaking skills, but lacking equivalent knowledge of grammar, reading, and writing Chinese characters. Prerequisite: Placement Test, CHINLANG 22B.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Second-Year Chinese for Bilingual Students, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of CHINLANG 22B, designed specifically for bilingual students who possess advanced listening and speaking skills in Chinese yet need further development in grammar, reading, and writing Chinese characters. Students will engage in immersive learning experiences, enhancing their grammatical understanding through practical exercises and dialogues. The curriculum focuses on expanding vocabulary and refining reading comprehension, while students practice writing characters to improve literacy. Through interactive discussions, multimedia resources, and collaborative projects, participants will enhance their linguistic proficiency and cultural awareness, preparing them for more advanced studies in Chinese language and literature.

original_descr: Continuation of CHINLANG 42. Repeatable once for units. Prerequisite: CHINLANG 23.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Intermediate-to-Advanced Chinese Conversation, Third Quarter

Course Description: This course serves as a continuation of CHINLANG 42, designed for students who wish to enhance their conversational proficiency in Mandarin Chinese. Building upon the foundations established in CHINLANG 23, participants will engage in dynamic discussions, role-playing scenarios, and group activities that promote fluency and confidence. Students will explore complex topics such as culture, politics, and current events, while expanding their vocabulary and refining their grammatical skills. Emphasis will be placed on listening comprehension and pronunciation. This course is repeatable for additional units, allowing students further opportunities for mastery and nuanced conversation.

course_title: Third-Year Modern Chinese for Bilingual Students, Third Quarter
original_descr: Continuation of CHINLANG 102B. Equivalent of CHINLANG 103. For students with advanced listening and speaking abilities, but lacking equivalent knowledge in reading and writing. Prerequisite: CHINLANG 102B.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Third-Year Modern Chinese for Bilingual Students, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course is a continuation of CHINLANG 102B and is equivalent to CHINLANG 103, designed specifically for bilingual students who possess advanced listening and speaking skills in Mandarin. However, these students may not have the same proficiency in reading and writing. Throughout the quarter, students will enhance their literacy by engaging with authentic texts, expanding vocabulary, and mastering complex grammatical structures. Interactive activities, such as discussions and presentations, will foster communication skills, while culturally relevant materials will deepen understanding of contemporary Chinese society. Prerequisite: successful completion of CHINLANG 102B is required for enrollment.

original_descr: Vocabulary and syntax of the classical language. Prerequisite: CLASSICS 2G or equivalent placement. CLASSICS 3G fulfills University language requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Beginning Greek

This foundational course introduces students to the vocabulary and syntax of ancient Greek, a pivotal language for understanding classical literature, history, and philosophy. Through engaging lectures, interactive exercises, and readings of selected texts, students will develop essential language skills, including grammar and sentence structure. Emphasis will be placed on translating prose and poetry, enabling students to appreciate the nuances of the language. Prerequisites include CLASSICS 2G or equivalent placement. Successful completion of CLASSICS 3G satisfies the University’s language requirement, making this course an excellent choice for those seeking to enhance their linguistic and cultural knowledge of the ancient world.

original_descr: Vocabulary and syntax of the classical language. Prerequisite: CLASSICS 2L or equivalent placement. CLASSICS 3L fulfills the University language requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Beginning Latin

In this introductory Latin course, students will explore the fundamental vocabulary and syntax of this classical language, laying a strong foundation for further study. Through a variety of engaging activities, including reading passages from ancient texts, students will gain insights into Roman culture and literature while developing their linguistic skills. Emphasis will be placed on understanding grammatical structures, enhancing translation abilities, and expanding vocabulary. This course is designed for those who have completed CLASSICS 2L or have equivalent placement knowledge. Successful completion of CLASSICS 3L will satisfy the University language requirement, enriching students' academic portfolios.

original_descr: Description forthcoming.
expanded_descr: In "Advanced Latin: Seneca's Moral Epistles," students will explore the profound philosophical insights of Seneca, one of Rome's most influential Stoic thinkers. This course delves into selected letters from Seneca's collection, focusing on themes such as ethics, virtue, and the human condition. Students will enhance their Latin language skills through close reading and analysis of the text, while also engaging with historical and cultural contexts. Class discussions will encourage critical thinking about the relevance of Stoic philosophy in contemporary life. By the end, students will gain a deeper appreciation of Seneca's contributions to literature and moral philosophy.

course_title: Undergraduate Directed Reading in Comparative Medicine
original_descr: May be taken as a prelude to research and may also involve participation in a lab or research group seminar and/or library research.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Undergraduate Directed Reading in Comparative Medicine

Expanded Description: This course offers students a unique opportunity to explore foundational concepts in comparative medicine through directed reading. Students will engage with primary literature and seminal texts, fostering critical thinking and analytical skills relevant to the field. Participation in a lab or research group seminar allows students to discuss findings, share insights, and collaborate with peers and faculty. Additionally, library research will enhance their understanding of current methodologies and advancements in comparative medicine. By the end of the course, students will be well-prepared for future research endeavors, equipped with knowledge and experience in this interdisciplinary area of study.

original_descr: Restricted to Computer Science and Electrical Engineering undergraduates.  Writing-intensive version of CS194. Preference given to seniors. Prerequisites: CS109 and CS161.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Software Project (WIM)

Expanded Description: This writing-intensive course, designed specifically for Computer Science and Electrical Engineering undergraduates, offers an immersive experience in software project development. Students will engage in comprehensive project planning, design, implementation, and documentation, honing their technical and communication skills. The course emphasizes collaborative teamwork and real-world problem-solving, allowing students to apply theoretical knowledge to practical applications. With a preference for seniors, participants will build on prerequisites CS109 and CS161, gaining valuable insights into software engineering principles and practices. By the end of the course, students will produce a polished project portfolio and enhance their professional writing capabilities.

original_descr: The elements of fiction writing: narration, description, and dialogue. Students write complete stories and participate in story workshops.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Fiction Writing

In this engaging Fiction Writing course, students will explore the essential elements of storytelling, including narration, vivid description, and authentic dialogue. Through a series of writing exercises, students will develop their unique voices while crafting complete short stories. Participants will engage in collaborative workshops, providing constructive feedback and learning to revise their work effectively. The course will also cover various narrative techniques and styles, allowing students to experiment with structure and character development. By the end of the course, students will have a portfolio of polished stories and a deeper understanding of the creative writing process.

original_descr: Historical and contemporary as a broad genre including travel and nature writing, memoir, biography, journalism, and the personal essay. Students use creative means to express factual content.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Creative Nonfiction

Expanded Description: This course delves into the rich and diverse genre of creative nonfiction, encompassing historical and contemporary works in travel writing, nature writing, memoir, biography, journalism, and personal essays. Students will explore the art of blending factual content with creative expression, honing their skills in storytelling and narrative construction. Through readings, discussions, and writing exercises, participants will learn to craft compelling narratives that resonate with authenticity and emotional depth. By analyzing various forms, students will develop their unique voice and style, ultimately producing polished pieces that reflect both their perspectives and the intricacies of real-life experiences.

original_descr: Issues of poetic craft. How elements of form, music, structure, and content work together to create meaning and experience in a poem.
expanded_descr: Course Description: In "Reading and Writing Poetry," students will explore the intricate interplay of poetic craft, delving into how form, rhythm, structure, and content coalesce to convey profound meaning and evoke emotional experiences. Through analyzing a diverse range of poems, participants will gain insight into various styles and techniques, enhancing their understanding of poetic voice and imagery. Writing exercises will encourage experimentation with different forms, fostering creativity and personal expression. By the end of the course, students will develop critical skills in both reading and crafting poetry, enabling them to appreciate the art form while honing their unique poetic voices.

course_title: Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies Honors Workshop
original_descr: Required of seniors in the Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies honors program. Particippants share ongoing work on their honors theses.  Prerequisite:  consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies Honors Workshop

Expanded Description: This workshop serves as a crucial capstone for seniors enrolled in the Feminist, Gender, and Sexuality Studies honors program. Participants will engage deeply with their ongoing research, sharing drafts and receiving constructive feedback from peers and the instructor. Emphasis will be placed on refining thesis arguments, enhancing analytical skills, and effectively articulating complex ideas. Additionally, students will explore interdisciplinary methodologies and frameworks, fostering a collaborative intellectual environment. This enriching experience not only prepares participants for their final thesis submissions but also encourages critical dialogue around contemporary issues in feminist, gender, and sexuality studies. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.

course_title: Queer and Trans History in Comparative Perspective
original_descr: This course explores the comparative history of queer and transgender desires, relationships, and identities through highlights of recent and classic scholarship on different periods and parts of the world.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Queer and Trans History in Comparative Perspective

Expanded Description: This course delves into the multifaceted history of queer and transgender identities, desires, and relationships across various cultures and historical periods. Students will engage with both classic and contemporary scholarship, examining how societal norms have shaped queer and trans experiences globally. Through critical analysis of primary texts, historical documents, and case studies, learners will uncover the intersections of sexuality, gender, and power. By comparing diverse perspectives, students will develop a nuanced understanding of the evolution of queer and trans histories, fostering critical thinking and promoting awareness of contemporary issues within LGBTQ+ communities worldwide.

course_title: Theories of the Moving Image: The Technologically Mediated Image
original_descr: This course examines influential theories of film and media from the early twentieth century to the present. Prerequisites: FILMEDIA 4.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Theories of the Moving Image: The Technologically Mediated Image

Expanded Description: This course provides an in-depth exploration of pivotal theories surrounding film and media, tracing their evolution from the early twentieth century to contemporary practices. Students will analyze key texts and concepts that have shaped our understanding of the moving image and its relationship with technology. Through lectures, discussions, and screenings, participants will engage critically with various theoretical frameworks, examining the impact of technological advancements on visual culture. By the end of the course, students will develop a nuanced perspective on how media influences perception, representation, and narrative in today’s digital landscape. Prerequisites: FILMEDIA 4.

original_descr: Analysis of quantitative and longitudinal data on national educational systems and political structures. May be repeated for credit. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Workshop: Comparative Sociology

Expanded Description: This workshop provides an in-depth analysis of quantitative and longitudinal data concerning various national educational systems and their corresponding political structures. Students will engage in hands-on data collection, interpretation, and comparison, enhancing their understanding of how different sociopolitical contexts influence educational outcomes. Through collaborative projects and discussions, participants will develop critical thinking skills and methodological expertise applicable to real-world scenarios. The course encourages students to explore diverse sociological theories while fostering an appreciation for cultural differences. Students may repeat the workshop for additional credit, with participation contingent upon obtaining consent from the instructor.

original_descr: Proficiency-based. Development of discourse appropriate in French and Francophone contexts. Prerequisite: no previous exposure to French
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year French, First Quarter

Expanded Description: This introductory course is designed for students with no prior exposure to the French language. Emphasizing proficiency, students will develop essential communication skills tailored for various French and Francophone contexts. Through engaging activities, including interactive dialogues, listening exercises, and cultural immersion, learners will practice vocabulary and grammatical structures that facilitate meaningful discourse. Topics will encompass everyday conversations, basic expressions, and cultural insights. Additionally, students will explore the rich tapestry of Francophone cultures, enhancing their global perspective. By the end of this course, students will confidently engage in basic conversations and express themselves in simple French.

original_descr: Continuation of FRENLANG 1. Proficiency-based. Development of discourse appropriate in French and Francophone contexts. Recent placement Test, completion of FRENLANG 1 or consent of French coordinator.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year French, Second Quarter

Expanded Description: This course is a continuation of FRENLANG 1, designed for students seeking to enhance their proficiency in French. Building on foundational skills, students will engage in interactive activities that foster the development of discourse suitable for diverse French and Francophone contexts. Emphasis will be placed on expanding vocabulary, improving grammar, and enhancing conversational abilities through immersive practices such as role-playing, discussions, and multimedia resources. Students will also explore cultural aspects, enriching their understanding of the Francophone world. Successful completion requires either a recent placement test, previous course completion, or the consent of the French coordinator.

original_descr: First-quarter of three-quarter First-Year Gerlang sequence. Emphasis is on developing beginning proficiency in interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational spheres.Prerequisite:  no experience with German or Placement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year German, First Quarter

Expanded Description: This course represents the first of a comprehensive three-quarter sequence designed for beginners in the German language. Students will focus on developing foundational proficiency across interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational communication skills. Through engaging activities such as dialogues, reading exercises, and presentations, learners will gain essential vocabulary and grammar, enabling them to navigate everyday situations in German. Cultural insights will enhance understanding and appreciation of German-speaking countries. No prior experience is required, making this an ideal starting point for those eager to explore the language. Placement tests are available for those with some previous exposure to German.

original_descr: Continuation of GERLANG1. Further development of socially and culturally appropriate proficiency in interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational spheres.Prerequisite: Placement, GERLANG1.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year German, Second Quarter

Expanded Description: This course is a continuation of GERLANG1, designed to enhance students' proficiency in German across interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational contexts. Students will engage in dynamic activities that promote conversational skills, listening comprehension, and reading proficiency, while exploring culturally relevant topics. Instruction will include interactive exercises, group discussions, and multimedia resources that foster deeper understanding of the German-speaking world. Prerequisite requirements include a successful placement or completion of GERLANG1. By the end of this quarter, students will be equipped with essential vocabulary and grammatical structures, enabling them to communicate effectively in everyday situations and cultural exchanges.

original_descr: Continuation of HEBRLANG 2. Prerequisite: Placement Test, HEBRLANG 2. Fulfill the University Foreign Language Requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Hebrew, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of HEBRLANG 2, enhancing students' proficiency in Hebrew through immersive language activities. Building on foundational grammar, vocabulary, and conversational skills, students will engage in reading, writing, and speaking exercises that emphasize practical application and cultural context. Course materials include contemporary texts, audio resources, and interactive dialogues, fostering a dynamic learning environment. Students will also explore aspects of Israeli culture and society to deepen their understanding of the language. Successful completion fulfills the University Foreign Language Requirement, preparing students for advanced study or personal enrichment in Hebrew language and culture.

original_descr: Continuation of HINDLANG 22. Prerequisite: HINDLANG 22.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Second-Year Hindi, Third Quarter

This course serves as a continuation of HINDLANG 22, building upon the foundational skills developed in previous Hindi language studies. Students will deepen their understanding of grammar, expand their vocabulary, and enhance their conversational proficiency through interactive exercises and immersive activities. Cultural context will be integrated, allowing learners to explore contemporary Indian society, literature, and traditions. Emphasis will be placed on reading and interpreting various texts, writing short essays, and engaging in discussions. By the end of the course, students will confidently communicate in Hindi while appreciating the nuances of language and culture. Prerequisite: HINDLANG 22.

original_descr: Continuation of IGBOLANG 2. Prerequisite: IGBOLANG 2. Fulfills the University Foreign Language requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Igbo, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of IGBOLANG 2, further enhancing students’ proficiency in the Igbo language through immersive learning experiences. Building on foundational vocabulary and grammar, students will engage in conversational practice, reading comprehension, and cultural exploration. The curriculum includes interactive activities, such as role-playing and group discussions, designed to reinforce language skills and promote fluency. Additionally, students will delve into various aspects of Igbo culture, traditions, and history, fostering a deeper understanding and appreciation of the language. Successful completion fulfills the University Foreign Language requirement, making it a vital step in language acquisition.

original_descr: Student-led courses in the arts. Topics change quarterly. Open to ALL students but current ITALIC students and alumni will be given priority.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Immersion in the Arts

Expanded Description: Immerse yourself in a vibrant exploration of the arts through this student-led course, where creativity knows no bounds. Each quarter, diverse topics will be introduced, allowing students to engage with various artistic disciplines, including visual arts, music, theater, and dance. Participants will collaborate, share ideas, and develop projects that reflect their passions and perspectives. Open to all students, this course particularly prioritizes current ITALIC students and alumni, fostering a dynamic community of artists. Enhance your skills, gain valuable insights, and connect with peers while celebrating the transformative power of the arts in a supportive environment.

course_title: First-Year Japanese Language, Culture, and Communication, First Quarter
original_descr: First-year sequence enables students to converse, write, and read essays on topics such as personal history, experiences, familiar people.  72 kanji characters will be taught.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Japanese Language, Culture, and Communication, First Quarter

Expanded Description: This introductory course immerses students in the basics of the Japanese language, focusing on conversational skills, reading, and writing. Students will engage in structured lessons that cover essential topics such as personal history, everyday experiences, and descriptions of familiar people, allowing for practical communication. Throughout the quarter, participants will learn to recognize and write 72 fundamental kanji characters, enhancing their literacy and understanding of Japanese culture. Interactive activities, including role-playing and cultural discussions, will enrich the learning experience, fostering a deeper appreciation of Japan’s traditions and social nuances while building a strong foundation for future language studies.

original_descr: Continuation of YDDSHLNG 2. Prerequisite: YDDSHLNG 2. Fulfills the University Foreign Language Requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Yiddish, Third Quarter

This course serves as a continuation of YDDSHLNG 2, designed for students who have successfully completed the prerequisite. In this third quarter, learners will deepen their understanding of Yiddish language and culture through expanded vocabulary, grammar, and conversational skills. Students will engage with authentic texts, including literature, songs, and films, to enhance comprehension and appreciation of Yiddish heritage. Emphasis will be placed on speaking and listening skills through interactive activities, fostering confidence in real-life communication. By the end of the course, students will have the foundational skills necessary to engage in basic conversations and explore Yiddish traditions.

original_descr: Continuation of KORLANG 102. Materials about Korean culture and society. Proficiency in interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational communication. Vocabulary, reading, and aural/oral skills. Prerequisite: Placement Test, or KORLANG 102.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Third-Year Korean, Third Quarter

This course is a continuation of KORLANG 102, designed to deepen students' understanding of the Korean language and its cultural context. Students will engage with a variety of materials that explore contemporary Korean society, enhancing their proficiency in interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational communication. Emphasis will be placed on expanding vocabulary, improving reading comprehension, and developing aural/oral skills through interactive activities and discussions. Students will also explore cultural themes relevant to modern Korean life, fostering a more nuanced appreciation of the language. Prerequisite: Successful completion of a placement test or KORLANG 102 is required for enrollment.

original_descr: Modules over PID. Tensor products over fields. Group representations and group rings. Maschke's theorem and character theory. Character tables, construction of representations. Prerequisite: Math 113 and 120.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Modules and Group Representations

In this course, students will explore the fascinating world of modules over principal ideal domains (PIDs) and delve into the intricacies of tensor products over fields. The curriculum will cover group representations and group rings, with a special emphasis on Maschke's theorem, which addresses the complete reducibility of representations over fields. Students will also study character theory, including the construction and interpretation of character tables. Through rigorous problem-solving and theoretical exploration, students will gain a deep understanding of how algebraic structures interact. A solid foundation in Math 113 and 120 is required for enrollment in this course.

original_descr: Class is closed by design.  Please contact instructor Erika Arul (mailto:earul@stanford.edu) for permission to enroll. Preference to Music majors and minors.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Ear Training II

Expanded Description: Ear Training II is an advanced course designed for students who have successfully completed Ear Training I. This class focuses on refining auditory skills essential for music comprehension, including interval recognition, chord identification, and rhythmic dictation. Students will engage in a variety of exercises, including singing, listening, and transcription, to enhance their musical ear. The course emphasizes practical applications in various musical styles and contexts. Enrollment is limited and by permission only, prioritizing Music majors and minors. Interested students should contact instructor Erika Arul at earul@stanford.edu for enrollment inquiries and to discuss prerequisites.

original_descr: Pre- or corequisite: 23.
expanded_descr: This course, "Music History Since 1830," explores the evolution of Western music from the Romantic era to contemporary styles. Students will examine significant composers, genres, and movements, including Romanticism, Impressionism, and Modernism. We will analyze notable works and their cultural contexts, focusing on how historical events influenced musical trends. Additionally, students will engage in listening exercises, discussions, and research projects to deepen their understanding of the relationship between music and society. By the end of the course, participants will be equipped with a comprehensive knowledge of key developments in music history and how they resonate in today’s musical landscape.

original_descr: Develop skills and techniques related to arranging for marching and concert bands; emphasizes instrumentation, transposition, and voicing.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Band Arranging

In this comprehensive course, students will immerse themselves in the art of arranging music specifically for marching and concert bands. Participants will develop essential skills and techniques, focusing on critical aspects such as instrumentation, transposition, and effective voicing. Through hands-on projects and collaborative exercises, students will explore various genres and styles, learning to craft arrangements that enhance performance quality and engage audiences. Additionally, the course will cover the use of software tools for arranging, helping students to realize their musical ideas. By the end of the course, students will confidently create original arrangements tailored for diverse band settings.

original_descr: Individual projects in composition, psychoacoustics, or signal processing. See http://ccrma.stanford.edu. May be repeated for credit. Prerequisite: 220B.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Research Seminar in Computer-Generated Music

This seminar offers an in-depth exploration of individual projects focusing on composition, psychoacoustics, and signal processing within the realm of computer-generated music. Students will engage in hands-on research, developing innovative sound compositions and analyzing auditory perception through psychoacoustic principles. Participants will also investigate advanced signal processing techniques to enhance their creative works. Emphasis is placed on interdisciplinary collaboration and critical listening skills. This course may be repeated for credit, allowing students to refine their projects and deepen their expertise. Prerequisite knowledge from course 220B is essential for a successful experience in this seminar.

original_descr: Techniques for organizing data, computing, and interpreting measures of central tendency, variability, and association. Estimation, confidence intervals, tests of hypotheses, correlation, and regression.
expanded_descr: In "Introduction to Statistical Methods: Precalculus," students will explore essential techniques for effectively organizing and analyzing data. The course covers the computation and interpretation of key measures, including central tendency, variability, and association, providing a foundational understanding of data relationships. Students will learn to construct and interpret confidence intervals, perform hypothesis testing, and apply correlation and regression analysis to real-world scenarios. Through hands-on projects and practical examples, participants will develop critical thinking skills necessary for data-driven decision-making. This course is designed to equip students with the statistical tools required for further study in various fields, enhancing their analytical capabilities.

original_descr: Continuation of POLSHLNG 102. Prerequisite: POLSHLNG 102.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Third-Year Polish, Third Quarter

This course serves as a continuation of POLSHLNG 102, designed for students who have successfully completed the second quarter of third-year Polish. Building on previously acquired language skills, students will deepen their understanding of Polish grammar, vocabulary, and sentence structure through immersive reading, writing, and conversation exercises. Emphasis will be placed on enhancing fluency and comprehension by engaging with contemporary Polish literature, media, and cultural topics. Students will participate in discussions, presentations, and collaborative projects, fostering an interactive learning environment. By the end of the quarter, students will confidently communicate on a variety of subjects in Polish.

original_descr: Continuation of PUNJLANG 2.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First Year Punjabi, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of PUNJLANG 2, designed to deepen students' understanding and proficiency in the Punjabi language. Building on foundational skills, students will enhance their vocabulary, grammar, and conversational abilities through engaging activities and real-life scenarios. The curriculum includes reading comprehension exercises, writing assignments, and cultural discussions that explore Punjabi traditions and customs. Students will participate in group discussions and presentations to improve fluency and confidence. By the end of this course, learners will be better equipped to communicate effectively in various contexts while appreciating the rich cultural heritage of Punjabi-speaking communities.

course_title: Writing & Rhetoric 1:  The Rhetoric of Biomedical Ethics
original_descr: Rhetorical and contextual analysis of readings; research; and argument. Focus is on development of a substantive research-based argument using multiple sources. Individual conferences with instructor.  See http://www.stanford.edu/dept/undergrad/cgi-bin/drupal_ual/AP_univ_req_PWR_Courses.html.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Writing & Rhetoric 1: The Rhetoric of Biomedical Ethics

In this course, students will engage in an in-depth rhetorical and contextual analysis of selected readings in biomedical ethics. The curriculum emphasizes the development of a well-researched, substantive argument that synthesizes multiple scholarly sources. Students will learn to critically evaluate ethical dilemmas in the biomedical field and articulate their perspectives effectively. Individual conferences with the instructor provide personalized feedback and guidance to enhance writing skills. By the end of the course, students will have honed their research capabilities and argumentative strategies, preparing them for advanced discourse in both academic and professional contexts.

original_descr: Continuation of SNSKTLNG 2. Prerequisite: SNSKTLNG 2. The completion of this course fulfills the University Language Requirement
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Sanskrit, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of SNSKTLNG 2, further enhancing students' understanding and proficiency in Sanskrit. Building on previously acquired skills, students will delve deeper into grammar, vocabulary, and sentence structure, enabling them to read and translate simple texts. Emphasis will be placed on conversational practice, fostering fluency and confidence in speaking. Additionally, the course will explore cultural and historical contexts of Sanskrit literature, enriching students’ appreciation of its significance. Successful completion of this course will fulfill the University Language Requirement and prepare students for advanced studies in language and literature.

original_descr: For undergraduates planning to conduct research during the summer with faculty in the Doerr School of Sustainability. Readings, oral presentations, proposal development.  May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Research Preparation for Undergraduates

Expanded Description: This course is designed for undergraduates eager to engage in summer research alongside faculty at the Doerr School of Sustainability. Students will explore foundational research methodologies, engage in critical readings relevant to their fields, and develop effective oral presentation skills. The course emphasizes the creation of well-structured research proposals, equipping students with the tools necessary to articulate their research questions and objectives clearly. Collaborative discussions and peer feedback sessions will foster a supportive learning environment. This course may be repeated for credit, allowing students to refine their skills and explore diverse research interests over multiple terms.

original_descr: Continuation of SWAHLANG 2. Prerequisite: SWAHLANG 2. Fulfills the University foreign language requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Swahili, Third Quarter

This course is a continuation of SWAHLANG 2, designed to deepen students' understanding of the Swahili language and culture. Building on prior knowledge, students will enhance their vocabulary, grammar, and conversational skills through interactive activities, including dialogues, role-playing, and multimedia resources. Cultural components will explore traditions, music, and literature, fostering a holistic appreciation for the Swahili-speaking world. Participation in group discussions and projects will encourage collaborative learning and practical application of language skills. Successful completion fulfills the University’s foreign language requirement, equipping students with essential communication competencies for personal and professional contexts in Swahili-speaking environments.

original_descr: Continuation of TURKLANG 22. The main focus is on class discussions and essay-writing practices about daily life in Turkey. End of quarter presentation in Turkish. Prerequisite: TURKLANG 22.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Second-Year Turkish, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of TURKLANG 22, enhancing students' proficiency in Turkish through immersive class discussions and focused essay-writing exercises that explore various aspects of daily life in Turkey. Students will engage with contemporary topics, cultural nuances, and social issues, fostering a deeper understanding of Turkish society. The curriculum emphasizes active participation and encourages students to express their thoughts and perspectives in Turkish. As a culmination of their learning, students will deliver a presentation in Turkish at the end of the quarter, showcasing their language skills and insights gained throughout the course. Prerequisite: TURKLANG 22.

original_descr: Continuation of UKRNLANG 2. Prerequisite: UKRNLANG 2. Completion of this course fulfills the language requirement.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Ukrainian, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of UKRNLANG 2, designed for students who have successfully completed the previous level. Building on foundational skills, students will enhance their proficiency in Ukrainian through immersive language practice, focusing on advanced vocabulary, grammatical structures, and conversational fluency. Emphasis will be placed on cultural contexts, enabling students to engage with authentic texts and media. Collaborative activities, including group discussions and presentations, will foster a supportive learning environment. Successful completion of this course not only fulfills the language requirement but also equips students with essential communication skills for further language studies and cultural appreciation.

original_descr: Grammatical structures, vocabulary, and sentence patterns through speaking, reading, writing, and listening. Urdu culture.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: First-Year Urdu, Third Quarter

In this immersive course, students will deepen their understanding of Urdu by exploring essential grammatical structures and expanding their vocabulary. Through engaging activities, learners will practice speaking, reading, writing, and listening skills to enhance their fluency and comprehension. The course will incorporate authentic materials, including literature and media, to expose students to the rich nuances of Urdu culture. Additionally, students will engage in conversational practice, enabling them to communicate effectively in real-life situations. By the end of this quarter, participants will possess a solid foundation in Urdu, fostering both language proficiency and cultural appreciation.

original_descr: Students undertake investigations sponsored by individual faculty members. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Undergraduate Research

In this hands-on course, students engage in original investigative projects under the mentorship of experienced faculty members. Participants will explore various research methodologies and techniques relevant to their field of study while contributing to ongoing scholarly work. The course emphasizes critical thinking, data analysis, and effective communication of research findings through presentations and written reports. Students will gain valuable insights into the research process, enhance their problem-solving skills, and develop a deeper understanding of their disciplines. Prerequisite for enrollment is the consent of the instructor, ensuring a tailored experience that aligns with individual academic interests and goals.

original_descr: Continuation of YDDSHLNG 22. Prerequisite: YDDSHLNG 22.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Second-Year Yiddish, Third Quarter

This course serves as a continuation of YDDSHLNG 22, focusing on advancing students' proficiency in the Yiddish language. Building on previously acquired skills, students will engage in immersive activities that enhance conversational fluency, reading comprehension, and cultural understanding. Through interactive exercises, literary analysis of Yiddish texts, and multimedia resources, learners will explore themes of identity, history, and tradition within Yiddish culture. Additionally, students will participate in group discussions and presentations to foster collaborative learning. By the end of the quarter, participants will have a deeper appreciation for Yiddish language and culture, preparing them for further studies.

original_descr: Finite deformations: strain and stress measures, balance laws, and constitutive models. Plasticity and fracture. Introduction to finite element analysis.
expanded_descr: In the Analysis of Structures course, students will delve into the intricate world of finite deformations, exploring essential concepts such as strain and stress measures, as well as the fundamental balance laws governing structural integrity. The curriculum includes an in-depth study of constitutive models, focusing on plasticity and fracture mechanics to understand material behavior under various loading conditions. Furthermore, students will receive a comprehensive introduction to finite element analysis (FEA), equipping them with the skills to model and solve complex structural problems. Through theoretical discussions and practical applications, participants will develop a robust foundation for analyzing and designing safe, efficient structures.

original_descr: Prerequisite: consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Directed Reading in Anesthesiology

Expanded Description: This course offers an in-depth exploration of anesthesiology through curated readings and discussions, tailored to individual interests and academic goals. Students will engage with seminal texts, contemporary research, and clinical case studies under the guidance of a faculty mentor. Emphasis will be placed on critical analysis, synthesis of information, and application of theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios in anesthesiology. Participants will develop a comprehensive understanding of anesthetic techniques, pharmacology, and patient safety. The course culminates in a presentation, allowing students to showcase their insights and foster dialogue among peers, enhancing their learning experience and professional development.

original_descr: Current research topics in lasers, quantum electronics, optics, and photonics by faculty, students, and invited outside speakers. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Optics and Electronics Seminar

Expanded Description: This seminar offers an in-depth exploration of cutting-edge research topics in lasers, quantum electronics, optics, and photonics. Students will engage with presentations from faculty, fellow students, and esteemed invited speakers from both academia and industry, fostering a collaborative learning environment. The seminar will cover recent advancements, innovative applications, and theoretical foundations, encouraging critical discussion and questions. Participants will gain insights into ongoing research projects and emerging technologies, enhancing their understanding of the field. This course may be repeated for credit, allowing students to deepen their knowledge and stay current with evolving trends in optics and electronics.

course_title: Intimacies as Method: Studying Black and Brown Relation
original_descr: Intimacies as Method: Studying Black and Brown Relation
expanded_descr: In "Intimacies as Method: Studying Black and Brown Relation," students will explore the intricate dynamics of relationships within Black and Brown communities. This course examines how intimacy shapes cultural identities, social structures, and resistance practices. Through a combination of theoretical frameworks, case studies, and personal narratives, participants will engage in critical discussions about the significance of relationality in understanding lived experiences. Students will also analyze various forms of intimacy—familial, communal, and political—while employing methods that prioritize empathy and connection. By the end of the course, students will develop a nuanced appreciation of intimacy as a vital tool for social inquiry and activism.

original_descr: Required of all teaching assistants in Chemistry. Techniques of teaching chemistry by means of lectures and labs.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Teaching of Chemistry

Expanded Description: This course is essential for all teaching assistants in the Chemistry department, focusing on effective instructional strategies tailored for chemistry education. Participants will explore various teaching methodologies, including lecture design, interactive learning, and laboratory instruction. Emphasis will be placed on fostering critical thinking and problem-solving skills among students. Through hands-on workshops, teaching assistants will develop lesson plans, engage in peer teaching, and receive constructive feedback. Additionally, the course will cover assessment techniques and student engagement strategies to create a dynamic learning environment. By the end, participants will be equipped to inspire and educate future chemists effectively.

original_descr: Required of graduate students. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Department Colloquium

Expanded Description: The Department Colloquium is a vital component of the graduate program, designed to enhance students' academic experience and professional development. This course offers a platform for students to engage with faculty and guest speakers, explore current research topics, and participate in discussions that foster critical thinking. Students will present their own research and receive constructive feedback, honing their presentation skills and academic discourse. The colloquium encourages networking and collaboration among peers, making it an invaluable opportunity for intellectual growth. Enrollment is required for all graduate students and can be repeated for additional credit throughout their studies.

original_descr: Quantum mechanics with examples related to spectroscopy. Includes time dependent perturbation theory, matrix formalism, density matrix formalism and angular momentum.  Required: CHEM 271 or equivalent quantum mechanics course.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Quantum Mechanics with Spectroscopy Examples

This course delves into the principles of quantum mechanics, emphasizing applications in spectroscopy. Students will explore fundamental concepts such as time-dependent perturbation theory, matrix formalism, and density matrix formalism, which are crucial for understanding quantum systems. Additionally, the course will cover angular momentum, providing students with a comprehensive framework to analyze quantum phenomena. Through a combination of theoretical lectures and practical examples from various spectroscopic techniques, students will gain insight into how quantum mechanics underpins the behavior of molecules and atoms. Prerequisite: CHEM 271 or an equivalent course in quantum mechanics is required for enrollment.

original_descr: Weekly lectures by experts from academia and industry in the field of chemical engineering. Course may be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Colloquium

Expanded Description: The Colloquium course offers students a unique opportunity to engage with weekly lectures delivered by esteemed experts in chemical engineering from both academia and industry. Each session will explore cutting-edge research, innovative technologies, and real-world applications that shape the future of the field. Students will not only gain insights into current trends and challenges but also participate in discussions that foster critical thinking and networking opportunities. This course encourages active participation and reflection on topics presented, enhancing students’ understanding and appreciation of chemical engineering. Students may repeat this course for additional credit, enriching their learning experience.

original_descr: Prepares ICME students for the qualifying exams by reviewing relevant course topics and problem solving strategies. Senior ICME students share experiences and lead discussions revolving around ICME core courses.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: ICME QUALIFYING EXAMS WORKSHOP

Expanded Description: This intensive workshop is designed to equip ICME students with the skills necessary to excel in their qualifying exams. Participants will engage in comprehensive reviews of essential topics across core courses, enhancing their understanding and reinforcing critical concepts. Experienced senior ICME students will lead interactive discussions, sharing invaluable insights and personal strategies for effective problem solving. Through collaborative problem-solving sessions and peer support, students will gain confidence and clarity in their approach to exam preparation. This workshop fosters a supportive learning environment, encouraging students to ask questions, share challenges, and develop effective study techniques for academic success.

original_descr: For students interested in research in political science, psychology, or communication. Methodological techniques for studying political attitudes and behaviors. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Graduate Seminar in Political Psychology

In this dynamic seminar, students delve into the intersection of political science, psychology, and communication, exploring the psychological underpinnings of political attitudes and behaviors. Through a combination of theoretical frameworks and empirical research, participants will engage with various methodological techniques, including surveys, experiments, and qualitative analyses. Students will critically evaluate existing literature and design their own research projects, fostering a deep understanding of how psychological factors shape political decision-making. This course encourages collaboration and discussion, making it an enriching experience for those aiming to advance their knowledge and skills in political psychology. May be repeated for credit.

original_descr: Topics: Pseudo randomness, multiparty computation, pairing-based and lattice-based cryptography, zero knowledge protocols, and new encryption and integrity paradigms. May be repeated for credit. Prerequisite: CS255.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Advanced Topics in Cryptography

Expanded Description: This course delves into sophisticated concepts in cryptography, emphasizing the role of pseudo randomness in secure systems. Students will explore multiparty computation techniques that enable collaborative data processing without compromising privacy. The curriculum includes an in-depth study of pairing-based and lattice-based cryptography, which are pivotal in modern cryptographic schemes. Additionally, participants will learn about zero-knowledge protocols that ensure information security without revealing the data itself. The course also introduces emerging encryption and integrity paradigms, fostering critical thinking and innovation. Prerequisite knowledge from CS255 is required. This course may be repeated for credit to deepen understanding.

original_descr: Restricted to Economics Ph.D. students. Students present current research. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Third-Year Seminar

Expanded Description: This seminar is exclusively designed for Economics Ph.D. students, fostering a collaborative environment where participants present and critique ongoing research projects. Students will engage deeply with contemporary economic theories and methodologies, enhancing their analytical and presentation skills. Each session encourages constructive feedback, promoting scholarly dialogue and peer learning. Additionally, students will explore various research topics, refining their own work while gaining insights from colleagues. The seminar can be taken multiple times for credit, allowing for continuous growth and development in research acumen. This course is essential for cultivating a robust academic foundation in economics research.

original_descr: Macroeconomic Seminar. Prerequisites: Econ 210, Econ 211 and Econ 212. To obtain credit, enrolled students need to satisfy the macro field presentation requirements.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Macroeconomic Seminar

Expanded Description: The Macroeconomic Seminar offers an in-depth exploration of advanced macroeconomic theories and their real-world applications. Building on foundational knowledge from Econ 210, Econ 211, and Econ 212, students will engage in rigorous discussions and critical analyses of current macroeconomic issues. The seminar format encourages active participation, requiring students to prepare and deliver presentations focused on specific macroeconomic topics. Participants will enhance their research skills and deepen their understanding of economic indicators, policy implications, and global economic trends. Successful completion of the presentation requirements is essential for earning credit, fostering both academic and professional growth in economics.

original_descr: Information and meeting times are available on the Department of Economics Website: https://economics.stanford.edu/seminars-events/list-seminars
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Development Seminar

Expanded Description: The Development Seminar offers students a dynamic platform to explore contemporary issues in economic development through a series of expert-led discussions and presentations. Participants will engage with leading researchers and practitioners in the field, examining topics such as poverty alleviation, sustainable growth, and policy interventions. This seminar encourages critical thinking and collaborative learning, allowing students to analyze real-world case studies and theoretical frameworks. Attendance and active participation are essential, as students will gain invaluable insights into the complexities of economic development. For schedules and additional information, please visit the Department of Economics website: https://economics.stanford.edu/seminars-events/list-seminars.

original_descr: Field seminar in experimental and behavioral economics.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Experimental/Behavioral Seminar

This seminar offers an in-depth exploration of experimental and behavioral economics, focusing on the intersection of psychology and economic decision-making. Students will engage with cutting-edge research methodologies, including laboratory and field experiments, to investigate how psychological factors influence economic behavior. Through discussions of seminal studies and contemporary findings, participants will learn to design their own experiments, analyze data, and critically evaluate results. The course emphasizes real-world applications, encouraging students to consider policy implications of behavioral insights. By the end, students will have a robust understanding of how experimental economics can inform better decision-making in various contexts.

original_descr: This seminar considers ongoing work in organization studies through a speaker series featuring Stanford faculty, visiting scholars, and guests from academic institutions throughout North America and elsewhere.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Seminar in Organizations and Institutions

Expanded Description: This engaging seminar delves into contemporary research in organization studies, fostering a dynamic learning environment through an interactive speaker series. Students will have the unique opportunity to hear from Stanford faculty, distinguished visiting scholars, and prominent guests from various academic institutions across North America and beyond. Each session will focus on cutting-edge topics, theories, and methodologies pertinent to organizational behavior, institutional dynamics, and management practices. Participants will critically analyze the implications of these insights, encouraging robust discussions and collaborative learning, and enhancing their understanding of how organizations operate within complex institutional frameworks.

original_descr: Current research topics. Presentations by guest speakers from Stanford and elsewhere. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: ESE Graduate Seminar

Expanded Description: The ESE Graduate Seminar offers an engaging platform for students to explore cutting-edge research topics in electrical and systems engineering. Through a series of presentations by esteemed guest speakers from Stanford University and other leading institutions, students will gain insights into current advancements and methodologies in the field. This seminar encourages active participation and critical discussion, allowing students to deepen their understanding of complex concepts and emerging technologies. By attending, students will not only enhance their academic knowledge but also expand their professional networks. The course may be repeated for credit, enabling ongoing exploration of evolving subjects.

original_descr: Strategies and conventions for graduate writing. Emphasis is placed on fluency, organization, documentation, and appropriateness for writing tasks required in coursework.  May be repeated once for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Writing Academic English

Expanded Description: This course provides graduate students with essential strategies and conventions for mastering academic writing. Students will focus on developing fluency in their writing style, organizing ideas cohesively, and adhering to proper documentation practices. Emphasis will be placed on the specific writing tasks required in various coursework, including research papers, essays, and presentations. Through guided practice, peer reviews, and instructor feedback, students will refine their skills and learn to tailor their writing to diverse academic audiences. This course may be repeated once for additional credit, allowing for continued growth and deeper exploration of academic writing techniques.

original_descr: Course designed to refine the proficiency and fluency in academic speaking and writing for non-native English speakers.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Advanced English for Non-Native Speakers

This comprehensive course is tailored for non-native English speakers seeking to elevate their academic speaking and writing skills to a professional level. Students will engage in intensive practice sessions focusing on advanced vocabulary, complex sentence structures, and effective argumentation techniques. Through interactive discussions, peer reviews, and presentations, participants will enhance their fluency and confidence in articulating ideas clearly. Additionally, the course will cover academic writing conventions, including thesis development and citation practices. By the end, students will be equipped with the tools necessary to succeed in an English-speaking academic environment and communicate effectively in diverse contexts.

original_descr: Superfluidity and superconductivity. Quantum magnetism. Prerequisite: PHYSICS 372.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Condensed Matter Theory II

Expanded Description: In Condensed Matter Theory II, students will delve into advanced topics such as superfluidity and superconductivity, exploring the underlying quantum mechanical principles that govern these fascinating phenomena. The course will also examine quantum magnetism, including the behavior of magnetic materials at the quantum level. Through a combination of theoretical framework and practical applications, students will develop a deeper understanding of how quantum effects influence macroscopic properties in condensed matter systems. Prerequisite knowledge from PHYSICS 372 is essential, ensuring that participants are prepared to engage with complex concepts and contribute to discussions on cutting-edge research in condensed matter physics.

original_descr: This graduate seminar will explore social-cognitive perspectives on motivation and emotion. Meetings will be discussion based. Prerequisites: Psychology 207 and consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Human Motivation

Expanded Description: This graduate seminar delves into the intricate dynamics of human motivation and emotion through social-cognitive perspectives. Students will engage in lively discussions, analyzing foundational theories and contemporary research that illuminate the psychological mechanisms driving behavior. Key topics include the interplay between intrinsic and extrinsic motivators, emotional regulation, and goal-setting strategies. Through collaborative discourse and critical analysis of case studies, participants will deepen their understanding of how motivation influences personal and social outcomes. Prerequisites include Psychology 207 and instructor consent, ensuring students are well-prepared to contribute to discussions and apply concepts to real-world situations effectively.

original_descr: Theory and research. Comparative and human research approaches map affective function to neuroanatomical and neurochemical substrates. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Affective Neuroscience

This course delves into the intricate relationship between emotions and brain function, emphasizing both theoretical frameworks and empirical research. Students will explore various methodologies, comparing findings from human studies with those from animal models to understand how affective processes are represented within neuroanatomical and neurochemical systems. Key topics include the neural correlates of emotion, the impact of neurotransmitters, and the evolutionary significance of affective responses. Through lectures, discussions, and hands-on research projects, students will critically analyze current literature and contribute to ongoing debates in the field. Enrollment requires the consent of the instructor, ensuring a focused learning environment.

original_descr: This course will cover the basic principles and rules regarding the taxation of domestic corporations. Elements used in grading: attendance, class participation, and final exam.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Corporate Income Taxation

Expanded Description: This comprehensive course delves into the fundamental principles and regulations governing the taxation of domestic corporations. Students will explore key topics such as taxable income determination, deductions, tax credits, and the implications of corporate tax structures. Through engaging lectures and interactive discussions, participants will gain a solid understanding of tax compliance, planning strategies, and the impact of tax legislation on corporate operations. Grading will be based on attendance, active participation in discussions, and a final exam that assesses students' grasp of course material. This course is essential for those pursuing careers in accounting, finance, and corporate law.

original_descr: History and literature. Institutional, ritual, affective, and symbolic aspects. Perspectives of gender, class, and social change.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: The Chinese Family

This course delves into the intricate history and literature surrounding the Chinese family, exploring its institutional, ritualistic, affective, and symbolic dimensions. Students will examine how gender roles, class structures, and social changes shape family dynamics across different historical periods. Through an analysis of literary texts, historical documents, and contemporary case studies, participants will gain insights into the evolving roles within the family unit, including the impact of modernization and globalization. Engaging discussions and collaborative projects will encourage students to critically reflect on the significance of family in Chinese society and its broader implications in a global context.

original_descr: Continuation of CZECLANG 22. Prerequisite: CZECLANG 22.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Second-Year Czech, Third Quarter

This course serves as a continuation of CZECLANG 22, building on the foundational skills developed in previous semesters.
