Students will enhance their proficiency in Czech through immersive activities that involve reading, writing, listening, and speaking. The curriculum focuses on expanding vocabulary, mastering complex grammatical structures, and improving conversational fluency. Cultural elements will be integrated, allowing students to explore Czech traditions, literature, and contemporary issues. Engaging group discussions, multimedia resources, and practical exercises will foster a collaborative learning environment. Prerequisite: Successful completion of CZECLANG 22 is required to ensure readiness for the advanced topics covered in this course.

original_descr: The focus of the course will be both on the generation of new work and on strategies to solve artistic problems through studies in poetic craft.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Advanced Poetry Writing

In this immersive course, students will delve into the intricacies of poetic craft, focusing on generating innovative new work while tackling common artistic challenges. Participants will explore various techniques, such as imagery, sound, and form, to enhance their writing. Through peer critiques and guided discussions, students will refine their voice and style, learning to articulate and resolve creative obstacles effectively. Additionally, the course will include analyses of contemporary and classic poetry, providing inspiration and context for their own writing. By the end, students will cultivate a robust portfolio and gain confidence in their poetic abilities.

original_descr: For undergraduates planning to conduct research during the summer with faculty through the MUIR and SUPER programs. Readings, oral presentations, proposal development. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Research Preparation for Undergraduates

Expanded Description: This course is designed for undergraduates eager to engage in research during the summer with faculty mentors through the MUIR and SUPER programs. Students will explore essential research methodologies, participate in critical readings, and enhance their communication skills through oral presentations. Emphasis will be placed on developing a compelling research proposal, equipping students with the tools needed to articulate their research ideas effectively. Collaborative discussions and peer feedback will foster a supportive learning environment. This course may be repeated for credit, allowing students to refine their skills and pursue diverse research interests throughout their academic journey.

course_title: Movies and Methods: Coming of Age Films
original_descr: TBD. Limited in size. Preference given to film and media studies seniors.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Movies and Methods: Coming of Age Films

This course delves into the rich genre of coming-of-age films, exploring their themes, narrative techniques, and cultural significance. Students will analyze a curated selection of films that capture the complexities of adolescence and personal growth, examining how filmmakers portray identity, relationships, and societal challenges. Through discussions, screenings, and critical essays, participants will develop a deeper understanding of cinematic storytelling and its impact on viewers. Limited in size to foster in-depth dialogue, this course prioritizes film and media studies seniors, encouraging them to engage critically with both classic and contemporary works in this compelling genre.

course_title: Introduction to Combinatorics and Its Applications
original_descr: Topics: graphs, trees (Cayley's Theorem, application to phylogony), eigenvalues, basic enumeration (permutations, Stirling and Bell numbers), recurrences, generating functions, basic asymptotics.
expanded_descr: Course Description: This course serves as a comprehensive introduction to combinatorics, exploring fundamental concepts and their diverse applications. Students will delve into graph theory, including the study of trees and Cayley's Theorem, with practical applications in phylogeny. The curriculum covers eigenvalues relevant to combinatorial structures, basic enumeration techniques such as permutations, and the use of Stirling and Bell numbers. Students will learn to solve recurrences and utilize generating functions as powerful tools for counting and analysis. Additionally, the course introduces basic asymptotic analysis, equipping students with essential skills to tackle complex combinatorial problems and real-world scenarios effectively.

original_descr: Readings from Heian, Kamakura, Muromachi, and early Edo periods with focus on grammar and reading comprehension. Prerequisite: JAPANLNG 129B or 103, or equivalent.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Introduction to Premodern Japanese

This course offers an in-depth exploration of readings from pivotal periods in Japanese history, including the Heian, Kamakura, Muromachi, and early Edo eras. Students will engage with a variety of texts, focusing on enhancing their understanding of classical Japanese grammar and improving reading comprehension skills. Emphasis will be placed on linguistic structures, historical context, and literary themes that shaped premodern Japanese culture. Through guided analysis and discussion, learners will develop a deeper appreciation for the intricacies of the language and its evolution. Prerequisites include JAPANLNG 129B or 103, or an equivalent background in Japanese language studies.

original_descr: Complex numbers, analytic functions, Cauchy-Riemann equations, complex integration, Cauchy integral formula, residues, elementary conformal mappings. (Math 116 offers a more theoretical treatment).
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Functions of a Complex Variable

Expanded Description: This course delves into the fascinating world of complex numbers and their applications in mathematics. Students will explore analytic functions and the pivotal Cauchy-Riemann equations, which establish the foundation for differentiability in complex analysis. Through rigorous study of complex integration, the course highlights the Cauchy integral formula and its implications. Additionally, learners will investigate the concept of residues and their significance in evaluating integrals. The curriculum will also cover elementary conformal mappings, showcasing their transformative properties. This course is ideal for those seeking practical applications of complex analysis while enhancing their analytical skills in this rich mathematical field.

original_descr: Introduction to smooth methods in topology including tranvsersality, intersection number, fixed point theorems, as well as differential forms and integration. Prerequisites: Math 144 or equivalent.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Differential Topology

Expanded Description: This course provides an in-depth introduction to the rich field of differential topology, focusing on smooth methods that illuminate the structure of manifolds. Students will explore essential concepts such as transversality, which facilitates the study of intersections within manifolds, and the intersection number, a fundamental invariant in topology. Additionally, the course covers fixed point theorems that have applications in various mathematical contexts. Emphasis is placed on differential forms and their role in integration on manifolds, equipping students with the necessary tools for advanced study. Prerequisites include Math 144 or an equivalent foundational course in mathematics.

original_descr: For undergraduates only. Classical and contemporary organization theory; the behavior of individuals, groups, and organizations. Limited enrollment; preference to declared MS&E majors and seniors from other departments.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Organizations: Theory and Management

Expanded Description: This undergraduate course explores both classical and contemporary organization theories, focusing on the dynamics of individual and group behavior within various organizational contexts. Students will engage in critical analysis of different management styles and organizational structures, examining how they influence performance and employee satisfaction. Through case studies, group discussions, and practical applications, participants will gain insights into real-world organizational challenges and strategies. The course is designed for a limited number of students, prioritizing declared Management Science and Engineering majors and senior students from other disciplines, ensuring a rich learning environment that fosters diverse perspectives.

original_descr: May be repeated for credit a total of 14 times. Zero unit enrollment option available with instructor permission. See website: (http://music.stanford.edu) for policy and procedure.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Classical Guitar Class

Expanded Description: This engaging Classical Guitar Class is designed for students of all skill levels, offering a comprehensive exploration of classical guitar techniques, repertoire, and performance practices. Students will learn fundamental skills, including fingerstyle techniques, sight-reading, and music theory, while developing a diverse repertoire that spans various historical periods and styles. The course encourages creativity and individual expression through group performances and collaborative projects. With opportunities to repeat the course for credit up to 14 times, students can deepen their understanding and mastery of the instrument. A zero-unit enrollment option is also available with instructor permission. Visit our website for details.

original_descr: Survey and analysis of a broad array of 20th-century examples, including compositional options.  Prerequisites: MUSIC 23 and MUSIC 24C; passing piano-proficiency examination; or, consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Introduction to Post-Tonal Analysis

Expanded Description: This course offers an in-depth exploration of post-tonal music, focusing on a diverse selection of 20th-century compositions. Students will engage in critical analysis of various musical styles and techniques, examining the compositional choices made by influential composers. Topics of study include twelve-tone techniques, atonality, modal systems, and contemporary harmonic structures. Through listening assignments, score analysis, and practical exercises, students will develop analytical skills necessary to interpret and understand modern music. Prerequisites include successful completion of MUSIC 23 and MUSIC 24C, along with passing a piano-proficiency examination or obtaining consent from the instructor for enrollment.

original_descr: Second-Year Navajo - third in series with NVJOLANG 21 and 22.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Second-Year Navajo, Third Quarter

This course, the third in the Second-Year Navajo series, builds upon the foundational skills acquired in NVJOLANG 21 and 22. Students will deepen their understanding of Navajo language structures, vocabulary, and cultural nuances through interactive lessons, storytelling, and immersive activities. Emphasis will be placed on developing conversational proficiency and reading comprehension, alongside exploring traditional narratives and contemporary contexts. Participants will engage in collaborative exercises that foster linguistic confidence while also gaining insights into Navajo culture, history, and customs. By the end of the course, students will enhance their ability to communicate effectively in Navajo and appreciate its rich heritage.

original_descr: Learn technical and safety skills pertaining to sport lead climibing. Apply specific physical and mental training principals to assist improving lead climbing performance and preventing over use injuries.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Indoor Lead Climbing

Expanded Description: This course focuses on the essential technical and safety skills required for sport lead climbing in an indoor environment. Students will engage in hands-on training that emphasizes proper belaying techniques, clip placement, and fall management. Additionally, participants will explore targeted physical conditioning exercises and mental strategies designed to enhance climbing performance and resilience. The curriculum includes injury prevention tactics, ensuring climbers understand their bodies' limits and how to avoid overuse injuries. By the end of the course, students will feel confident in their abilities to lead climb safely and effectively, ready to tackle more challenging routes.

original_descr: Continuation of PERSLANG 102. Prerequisite: Placement Test, PERSLANG 102.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Third-Year Persian, Third Quarter

Expanded Description: This course serves as a continuation of PERSLANG 102, designed for students who have successfully completed the prerequisite or placed into this level through a placement test. Throughout the quarter, students will deepen their understanding of Persian language structures, vocabulary, and cultural nuances. Emphasis will be placed on advanced reading, writing, and conversational skills, enabling students to engage with a variety of texts and discussions. Multimedia resources, literary works, and contemporary Persian media will enrich the learning experience. Students will also explore aspects of Persian culture, enhancing their language proficiency and cultural appreciation.

original_descr: A survey of foundational texts from the early analytic period, with primary readings from Frege, Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Ramsey, Carnap, Strawson and Quine. Pre-requisite: at least one philosophy class.
expanded_descr: This course offers an in-depth survey of the foundational texts that shaped analytic philosophy from 1884 to 1953. Students will engage critically with primary readings from key philosophers, including Frege, Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Ramsey, Carnap, Strawson, and Quine. Through rigorous analysis and discussion, participants will explore pivotal concepts such as meaning, reference, and logical structure, while examining the philosophical shifts that influenced contemporary thought. The course emphasizes the development of analytical techniques and their implications for various philosophical inquiries. A prerequisite of at least one philosophy class ensures that students are prepared for this intellectually stimulating journey into analytic tradition.

original_descr: Grads enroll in 273A.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Moral Psychology

Expanded Description: This course, designated as 273A for graduate students, delves into the intricate relationship between moral reasoning and psychological processes. Students will explore foundational theories of moral development, the role of emotions in ethical decision-making, and the impact of social influences on moral behavior. Through engaging discussions and critical analyses of contemporary research, participants will examine case studies that illustrate moral dilemmas in various contexts. The course encourages students to reflect on their moral beliefs and consider how psychological principles shape our understanding of morality. By the end, students will gain valuable insights applicable to both personal and professional realms.

original_descr: Theories of and approaches to understanding the phenomenology, etiology, and treatment of psychological disorders among adults and children. Research findings and diagnostic issues. Recommended: PSYCH 1.
expanded_descr: In "Introduction to Abnormal Psychology," students will explore the complexities of psychological disorders affecting both adults and children. This course emphasizes various theoretical frameworks and approaches to understanding the phenomenology—how disorders manifest—and the etiology, or underlying causes, of mental health issues. Students will engage with current research findings, examining diagnostic criteria and methodologies for assessing psychological disorders. Additionally, the course will cover contemporary treatment options, including psychotherapeutic and pharmacological interventions. Through case studies, discussions, and critical analysis, students will develop a comprehensive understanding of abnormal psychology, equipping them with knowledge applicable to real-world mental health contexts. Recommended: PSYCH 1.

original_descr: Join SPARQ (Social Psychological Answers to Real-world Questions) as a research assistant and help with projects addressing real-world issues.
expanded_descr:
Course Description: 

Join SPARQ (Social Psychological Answers to Real-world Questions) as a research assistant and engage in meaningful projects that address pressing real-world issues through the lens of social psychology. In this hands-on course, you'll collaborate with faculty and peers to design, implement, and analyze research studies that tackle topics such as social justice, health behaviors, and community dynamics. Students will develop critical research skills, learn data collection methods, and gain experience in statistical analysis. This opportunity not only enhances your understanding of social psychological principles but also empowers you to contribute to impactful solutions in society, fostering both personal and professional growth.

original_descr: Continuation of RUSSLANG 102. A snapshot of Russian life. Reading comprehension, conversational competence, grammatical accuracy, and cultural sophistication. Prerequisite: Placement Test or RUSSLANG 102.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Third-Year Russian, Third Quarter

original_descr: Continuation of TIGRYLNG 2. Prerequisite TIGRYLNG 2. Fulfills the University Foreign Language requirement.

original_descr: The practical application of urban design theory. Projects focus on designing neighborhood and downtown regions to balance livability, revitalization, population growth, and historic preservation.
expanded_descr:

Through site analysis, community engagement, and design workshops, participants will develop comprehensive urban design proposals that address real-world challenges. By integrating sustainability and social equity into their designs, students will learn to create vibrant, inclusive urban spaces that reflect the needs of diverse communities, ultimately preparing them for careers in urban planning and design.

original_descr: Required graduate seminar. The history of anthropological theory and key theoretical and methodological issues of the discipline. Prerequisite: consent of instructor.
expanded_descr:

Through discussions, readings, and practical assignments, participants will deepen their understanding of contemporary issues within the field. original_descr: May be repeated for credit.

original_descr: Introduction to the dynamic response of wind energy systems, such as wind energy technology, aerodynamics, and structural and electrical aspects.  Pre-requisites: CEE 280, CEE 282, CEE 283

This course is essential for preparing students for careers in academia and industry.

course_title: Social Responses to Technology from TV to AI

original_descr: An investigation of central issues in the study of the interface between syntax and morphology.
expanded_descr:

Class discussions, hands-on exercises, and research projects will enhance critical thinking and analytical skills. By the end of the course, students will be equipped to articulate the complexities of morphosyntactic interfaces and contribute to ongoing debates in the field of linguistics.

original_descr: The quantitative study of linguistic variability in time, space, and society emphasizing social constraints in variation. Hands-on work with variable data.

By the end of the course, students will develop a nuanced understanding of the dynamics of language variation, equipping them with essential skills for research, sociolinguistics, and data analysis in linguistic studies.

original_descr: Introduction to vectors and tensors: kinematics, deformation, forces, and stress concept of continua; balance principles; aspects of objectivity; hyperelastic materials; thermodynamics of materials; variational principles.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Continuum Mechanics

original_descr: Focus is on time-dependent random phenomena. Topics: discrete time Markov chains, Markov jump processes, queueing theory, and applications. Emphasis on model-building, computation, and related calibration and statistical issues.

Emphasis will be placed on model-building techniques, computational methods, and the calibration of stochastic models. Additionally, students will address statistical issues related to these models, fostering a comprehensive understanding of how to effectively apply stochastic processes in various fields, including finance, telecommunications, and operations research.

original_descr: Organization theory; concepts and functions of management; behavior of the individual, work group, and organization. Emphasis is on cases and related discussion.

original_descr: Illustrated discussions of compositional issues and techniques.  Presentation of relevant topics, including students' own compositional practice. May be repeated for credit a total of 14 times.

original_descr: Research seminar. Frontiers in mass political behavior. Course may be repeated for credit.

original_descr: Priority to Sociology doctoral students. Emphasis is on observational and interview-based research. Limited enrollment.

Additionally, the seminar emphasizes the importance of academic networking and mentorship, providing invaluable opportunities for building relationships with faculty and fellow colleagues. Enrollment is strictly by permission number, ensuring a tailored educational experience.

original_descr: Current topics in phonological theory and analysis. Meetings consist of presentations of ongoing research, collaborative work, and discussions of theoretical and methodological advances in the field.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Phonology Research Lab

In the Phonology Research Lab, students will engage with contemporary issues in phonological theory and analysis through a hands-on, collaborative approach. The course includes regular presentations of ongoing student research projects, fostering a dynamic environment for feedback and refinement. Participants will also explore cutting-edge theoretical frameworks and methodological advancements in phonology, enhancing their analytical skills. Discussions will encourage critical thinking and the application of concepts to real-world linguistic data. By the end of the course, students will have developed a deeper understanding of phonological patterns, as well as research skills applicable to future academic or professional endeavors.

original_descr: Restricted to Linguistics Ph.D. students. Student presentations of research toward qualifying papers. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Research Workshop

This specialized workshop is exclusively designed for Linguistics Ph.D. students, focusing on the presentation and discussion of research projects aimed at qualifying papers. Students will engage in a collaborative learning environment, enhancing their critical thinking and presentation skills while receiving constructive feedback from peers and faculty. Participants will explore various research methodologies, refine their arguments, and effectively communicate complex linguistic concepts. Additionally, the course encourages iterative revision based on peer critiques, fostering an atmosphere of academic growth. Students may enroll multiple times for credit, allowing for continued development of their research and presentation abilities throughout their doctoral studies.

original_descr: For Ph.D. students in their first or second year who are or are about to be teaching assistants for the department. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Teaching Methods in Philosophy

This course is specifically designed for first- and second-year Ph.D. students preparing to serve as teaching assistants within the philosophy department. Participants will engage in practical training focused on effective pedagogical techniques tailored to philosophy instruction. The curriculum includes developing lesson plans, fostering critical thinking, and employing various assessment strategies to enhance student learning. Additionally, students will participate in peer teaching exercises and receive constructive feedback to refine their skills. By the end of the course, participants will be equipped with the tools necessary to facilitate engaging discussions and create a supportive learning environment. May be repeated for credit.

original_descr: For graduate students. Faculty, guest speakers, and graduate students conducting research in political theory present works-in-progress. May be repeated for credit.
expanded_descr:
Course Title: Workshop in Political Theory

Expanded Description: This graduate-level workshop offers a collaborative platform for students to engage deeply with contemporary political theory. Participants will present their research works-in-progress, receiving constructive feedback from faculty members, guest speakers, and fellow graduate students. The course emphasizes critical discussion, fostering an environment where diverse perspectives are valued. By analyzing various theoretical frameworks and methodologies, students will refine their arguments and enhance their analytical skills. Additionally, the workshop encourages networking opportunities with established scholars in the field. Repeat enrollment is permitted, allowing students to further develop their research projects and contribute to the ongoing discourse in political theory.
